description: From New Latin Anoura, Anura (“name of the order of amphibians”), or from French Anoures (“name of a family of amphibians”) (from Latin an-, from Ancient Greek ἀν- (an-), from Proto-Indo-European *n̥- (“prefix meaning ‘not’”) + Ancient Greek οὐρά (ourá, “tail”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *h₃érsos (“backside, buttocks”))  +‎ -n (from Latin -ānus (“suffix meaning ‘of or pertaining to’”), from -nus, from Proto-Indo-European *-nós (“suffix creating adjective nouns from verbs”)).

entries.meaning: (batrachology) Of or relating to the order Anura.
(batrachology) Any amphibian of the order Anura; a frog, a toad.
